prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We apply for standard continuum observations, which provide the largest available bandwidth. Band 6 was chosen because of the combination of the available time in a the long baseline telescope configurations providing high enough angular resolution (C36-7 will be available twice) and the weather restrictions.

The average radius of a protoplanetary disk is ~100 AU. The distance of NGC 2264 is ~800 pc, therefore the angular diameter of a disk is 0.25". In order to be able to determine the spatial orientation of the disks we need at least 4-5 pixels, which means 50-60 mas.

Since we will observe resolved protoplanetary disks, a S/N of 3 per synthesized beam is enough for the detection. Note that the calculated flux densities are only lower limits and the actual brightness in Band 6 can be much higher.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Faint targets
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Targets with faint protoplanetary disks, therefore the recommended rms is lower.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We apply for standard continuum observations, which provide the largest available bandwidth. Band 6 was chosen because of the combination of the available time in a the long baseline telescope configurations providing high enough angular resolution (C36-7 will be available twice) and the weather restrictions.

The average radius of a protoplanetary disk is ~100 AU. The distance of NGC 2264 is ~800 pc, therefore the angular diameter of a disk is 0.25". In order to be able to determine the spatial orientation of the disks we need at least 4-5 pixels, which means 50-60 mas.

Since we will observe resolved protoplanetary disks, a S/N of 3 per synthesized beam is enough for the detection. Note that the calculated flux densities are only lower limits and the actual brightness in Band 6 can be much higher.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Bright targets
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Targets with bright protoplanetary disks, therefore the recommended rms is higher.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We apply for standard continuum observations, which provide the largest available bandwidth. Band 6 was chosen because of the combination of the available time in a the long baseline telescope configurations providing high enough angular resolution (C36-7 will be available twice) and the weather restrictions.

The average radius of a protoplanetary disk is ~100 AU. The distance of NGC 2264 is ~800 pc, therefore the angular diameter of a disk is 0.25". In order to be able to determine the spatial orientation of the disks we need at least 4-5 pixels, which means 50-60 mas.

Since we will observe resolved protoplanetary disks, a S/N of 3 per synthesized beam is enough for the detection. Note that the calculated flux densities are only lower limits and the actual brightness in Band 6 can be much higher.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: NGC 2264 is a young (3 Myr) open cluster containing about 2000 stars. Using time-series photometry from the Berlin Exoplanet Search Telescope II, we found that the frequency of detached eclipsing binaries increases significantly towards the centre of the cluster (Klagyivik et al. 2013). This suggests that the angular momentum vector of the parental cloud was once perpendicular to the line-of-sight and therefore the orbital planes of the binaries are parallel and edge-on. If this is true, then there is a verifiable prediction. The cluster is young and many stars still have a circumstellar disk. We expect much more edge-on disks than in the case of a random spatial distribution. We propose to use the ALMA facility in order to detect protoplanetary disks around the cluster member eclipsing binaries as well as to observe the disks of known non-binaries with disks and to check their spatial orientation.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Research Division, Astrophysical Institute of Canarias

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Research Division, Astrophysical Institute of Canarias
